item.title: The man leading Russia's war in Ukraine is out in a surprise shake-up hinting at Putin’s true focus
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Keir Simmons and Natasha Lebedeva
item.description: This weekend's ouster Sergei Shoigu as Russia's defense minister follows a corruption scandal and a calamitous start to Russia’s invasion of Kraine.

media:content.media:text: Russian President Vladimir Putin has proposed removing Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu from his post. Putin nominated First Deputy Prime Minister Andrey Belousov for the role.
media:content.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin, left and his Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu during Victory Day celebrations in Moscow on May 9, 2024.

media:content.media:text: New Russian Defense Minister Andrey Belousov
media:content.media:description: Andrey Belousov, then the first deputy prime minister in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Troop movement suggests Israel could expand operations in Rafah soon, U.S. officials say
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Courtney Kube and Gabe Gutierrez and Phil Helsel and Raf Sanchez
item.description: The U.S. has seen recent troop movement that indicates Israel could expand operations in Rafah soon, but it has not made a formal assessment about whether a full-scale invasion is imminent, according to two U.S. officials.

media:content.media:text: israel hamas conflict smoke destruction explosion
media:content.media:description: Smoke billows during Israeli strikes in eastern Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on May 13, 2024.

item.title: Orcas sink sailing yacht in Strait of Gibraltar
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: An unknown number of orcas have sunk a sailing yacht after ramming it in Moroccan waters in the Strait of Gibraltar, Spain’s maritime rescue service said on Monday.

media:content.media:text: The Rock of Gibraltar is seen from a ferry in the Strait of Gibraltar
media:content.media:description: The Rock of Gibraltar viewed from a ferry in the Strait of Gibraltar, off southern Spain, in January 2023.

item.title: Jewish groups add more allegations of antisemitism to their lawsuit against UC Berkeley
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: Two Jewish advocacy organizations suing the University of California, Berkeley, over a “longstanding, unchecked spread of anti-Semitism” have amended their complaint to include incidents from antiwar protests.

media:content.media:text: Erwin Chemerinsky smiles for a portrait
media:content.media:description: A lawsuit filed by Jewish advocacy groups alleges UC Berkeley tolerated an antisemitic campaign against its law school dean, Erwin Chemerinsky, seen here in 2021.

item.title: Duke students walk out of Jerry Seinfeld's commencement speech amid wave of anti-war protests
item.dc:creator: Doha Madani and Rebecca Cohen
item.description: Comedian Jerry Seinfeld was met with a wave of boos Sunday when students at Duke University in North Carolina walked out just before his commencement speech, the latest in a wave of antiwar protests at college graduations across the country this weekend.

media:content.media:text: Jerry Seinfeld
media:content.media:description: Jerry Seinfeld in Los Angeles on April 30, 2024.

item.title: Battles rage across Gaza as death toll tops 35,000 and tens of thousands evacuate Rafah
item.dc:creator: Hala Gorani and Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: Battles between Israeli forces and Hamas across Gaza after thousands people heeded evacuation orders to seek shelter elsewhere in the enclave.

media:content.media:text: Displaced Palestinians evacuate along a road of rubble
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians evacuate from the Tal al-Zaatar camp for Palestinian refugees in Gaza on May 11, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises above damaged buildings
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises above buildings during an early morning Israeli strike on Rafah, Gaza, on Saturday.

media:content.media:text: Palestinian civilians flee Rafah in southern Gaza
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians transport their belongings on the back of a truck as they move to a safer area in Rafah, Gaza, on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip is brought to a hospital in Rafah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Many Iranian Jews in 'Tehrangeles' say their allegiance is to Israel, not Iran
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: As pro-Palestinian protesters clash with counter-protesters at U.S. colleges, among the most vocal defenders of Israel are members of the Iranian-Jewish community.

media:content.media:text: Photo collage of Abby Yosian and a campus counter-protest at UCLA
media:content.media:description: Abby Yosian, right, made a new friend from Israel, Charlotte Korchak, left, at an outdoor Passover seder near the University of Southern California.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: U.S. citizens are languishing in Chinese prisons with little hope of release
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Abigail Williams and Dan De Luce and Rae Wang
item.description: As Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited China this week, the most important issue for hundreds of families in the U.S. was when their loved ones imprisoned in the country are coming home.

media:content.media:text: Nelson Wells Jr of Bossier City, La., who is currently detained in China.
media:content.media:description: Nelson Wells Jr. has been imprisoned in China for almost a decade.

item.title: They were promised jobs in Russia. They ended up fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Muheet Ul Islam
item.description: Families of Indian migrant workers forced to fight alongside the Russian army in Ukraine say they feel they have no choice but to travel there to help them.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Relatives of Azad Yousuf Kumar at his home in the Pulwama district of Indian-administered Kashmir in February.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Raja Begum, Kumar’s mother, displaying his photo as he wears a military uniform.

item.title: China's stressed and overworked youth skip the tea and reach for coffee
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Dawn Liu and Rae Wang
item.description: China has overtaken in the U.S. with the most branded coffee shops in the world as young people start drinking coffee to cope with a competitive job market and workplace.

media:content.media:text: A barista prepares drinks at a coffee shop in Beijing on March 6th, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A barista prepares drinks at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.
media:content.media:description: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.

media:content.media:text: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.

item.title: Museum curator accused of smuggling scorpion and spider samples
item.description: Lorenzo Prendini, an expert on arachnids at New York's American Museum of Natural History, was held by police at Istanbul Airport while allegedly trying to take about 1,500 samples out of the country.

media:content.media:title: Museum curator accused of smuggling scorpion and spider samples
media:content.media:description: Lorenzo Prendini, an expert on arachnids at New York's American Museum of Natural History, was held by police at Istanbul Airport while allegedly trying to take about 1,500 samples out of the country.

item.title: Israel fighting Hamas again in northern Gaza as hundreds of thousands flee Rafah
item.description: Israel is fighting a resurgence of Hamas militants in northern Gaza, while in the south, 360,000 people have fled Rafah to avoid Israeli strikes on the city. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

media:content.media:title: Israel fighting Hamas again in northern Gaza as hundreds of thousands flee Rafah
media:content.media:description: Israel is fighting a resurgence of Hamas militants in northern Gaza, while in the south, 360,000 people have fled Rafah to avoid Israeli strikes on the city. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

item.title: U.S. museum curator detained in Turkey for trying to smuggle dead spiders, scorpions
item.description: Turkish police detained Lorenzo Prendini, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, at Istanbul Airport after he allegedly attempted to smuggle about 1,500 spider and scorpion samples.

media:content.media:title: U.S. museum curator detained in Turkey for trying to smuggle dead spiders, scorpions
media:content.media:description: Turkish police detained Lorenzo Prendini, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, at Istanbul Airport after he allegedly attempted to smuggle about 1,500 spider and scorpion samples.

item.title: Thousands protest in Georgia against ‘foreign agents’ bill
item.description: Thousands gathered outside parliament in Georgia’s capital Tbilisi to protest against a controversial “foreign agents” bill that has sparked a political crisis in the country. Two U.S. citizens were among those detained during overnight demonstrations aimed at blocking lawmakers from entering the building.

media:content.media:title: Thousands protest in Georgia against ‘foreign agents’ bill
media:content.media:description: Thousands gathered outside parliament in Georgia’s capital Tbilisi to protest against a controversial “foreign agents” bill that has sparked a political crisis in the country. Two U.S. citizens were among those detained during overnight demonstrations aimed at blocking lawmakers from entering the building.

item.title: LGBTQ community in progressive Argentina says President Milei has turned back the clock
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Few in Argentina are more enraged by right-wing President Javier Milei’s anti-woke agenda than LGBTQ+ activists, who worry his new government is rolling back their hard-won gains.

media:content.media:text: Javier Milei delivers a speech
media:content.media:description: An LGBTQ activist said that under President Milei, "we are going backward."

media:content.media:text: Luana Salva, a trans woman, poses for a portrait
media:content.media:description: Luana Salva was ecstatic when a law promoted the inclusion of transgender people in the workforce — but she lost her job amid Milei's slashing of public spending and dismantling of DEI programs.

item.title: U.S. museum curator allegedly tried to smuggle 1,500 dead spiders and scorpions out of Turkey
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A curator at the American Museum of Natural History was detained in Istanbul on Monday while allegedly attempting to smuggle spider and scorpion samples, Turkish media reported.

media:content.media:text: Scorpion in a test tube on a table of evidence
media:content.media:description: Scorpions and spiders from Turkey, found in a smuggling operation in Istanbul, on May 13, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Bags containing scorpions and spiders displayed on a table during a press conference
media:content.media:description: Bags containing various scorpions and spiders from Turkey found in an alleged smuggling operation in Istanbul on Monday.

item.title: 3rd trespassing reported at Drake's mansion as man from previous incident comes back for bike
item.dc:creator: Marlene Lenthang and Diana Dasrath
item.description: A third trespassing incident unfolded Saturday at Drake’s Toronto mansion, authorities said.

media:content.media:text: Drake stands onstage during a concert
media:content.media:description: Drake during his "Till Death Do Us Part" rap battle in Long Beach, Calif., on Oct. 30, 2021.

item.title: Catalan separatists lose majority as Spain's pro-union Socialists win regional elections
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Six years after plunging Spain into its worst political crisis in decades, Catalonia’s separatist parties are in danger of losing their hold on power in the northeastern region after the pro-union Socialist Party scored a historic result in Sunday’s election.

media:content.media:text: Socialist candidate Salvador Illa makes a toast with members of his team and party colleagues after the announcement of the results of elections to the Catalan parliament in Barcelona.
media:content.media:description: Salvador Illa after the announcement of the results of elections to the Catalan parliament in Barcelona, on May 12, 2024.

item.title: Two Americans detained in Georgia as thousands protest 'Russia-style' law on foreign influence
item.dc:creator: Reuters and The Associated Press
item.description: Two U.S. citizens and one Russian were among 20 people detained at protests in Tbilisi while Georgian lawmakers were debating a “foreign agents” bill that has sparked a political crisis, the interior ministry said on Monday.

media:content.media:text: Daily protests are continuing against a proposed bill that critics say would stifle media freedom and obstruct the country's bid to join the European Union.
media:content.media:description: Police officers block demonstrators near the Parliament building in Tbilisi, Georgia on May 13, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Daily protests are continuing against a proposed bill that critics say would stifle media freedom and obstruct the country's bid to join the European Union.
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators waved Georgian national flags early Monday during the opposition protest in the center of Tbilisi.

item.title: Australian court lifts order blocking X on church stabbing video
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: An Australian court on Monday refused to extend a temporary order for Elon Musk-owned X to block videos of the stabbing of an Assyrian church bishop.

media:content.media:text: An Australian court on Monday rejected a bid by the country’s cyber safety regulator to extend a temporary order for Elon Musk-owned X to block videos of the stabbing of an Assyrian church bishop, which authorities had called a terrorist attack.
media:content.media:description: Tributes outside Christ the Good Shepherd church in suburban Sydney, where a bishop was stabbed last month in a livestreamed attack.

item.title: Floods kill 37 in Indonesia's West Sumatra
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Flash floods and mud slides in Indonesia’s West Sumatra province killed at least 43 people over the weekend while 15 others are missing, officials said Monday.

media:content.media:text: At least 34 people have died and 16 more were missing after flash floods and cold lava flow from a volcano hit western Indonesia, a local disaster official said on May 12.
media:content.media:description: Roads and homes severely damaged after flash floods and cold lava flow from a volcano in Tanah Datar, West Sumatra, on May 12, 2024.

media:content.media:text: At least 34 people have died and 16 more were missing after flash floods and cold lava flow from a volcano hit western Indonesia, a local disaster official said on May 12.
media:content.media:description: Vehicles lie stranded in a river in West Sumatra on Sunday.

item.title: Chinese woman jailed over Covid reporting in Wuhan is set to be freed
item.dc:creator: Mithil Aggarwal and Rae Wang
item.description: A Chinese citizen journalist who was jailed over her reporting on the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic was due to be released Monday, supporters said.

media:content.media:text: An undated file photo of Chinese activist Zhang Zhan. The 38-year-old lawyer turned citizen journalist was jailed for 4 years
media:content.media:description: Chinese citizen journalist Zhang Zhan was jailed for four years for reporting on the Covid-19 outbreak in Wuhan.

media:content.media:text: Visual Artists Guild will hold a horse-drawn caravan funeral procession in memory of the victims of COVID-19.
media:content.media:description: A car carrying a poster of Zhang in Pasadena, Calif., in 2020.

item.title: Sherpa Kami Rita scales Mount Everest for 29th time, extending his own record
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: One of the greatest climbing guides on Mount Everest has scaled the world’s highest peak for the 29th time, extending his own record.

media:content.media:text: One of greatest climbing guides on Mount Everest has scaled the world’s highest peak for the 29th time, extending his own record for most times to the summit, expedition organizers said Sunday.
media:content.media:description: Kami Rita in Kathmandu, Nepal, last year.

item.title: Plane with 3 aboard lands without landing gear at Australian airport after burning off fuel
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A light plane with three people aboard landed safely without landing gear Monday after circling an Australian airport for almost three hours to burn off fuel.

media:content.media:text: A light plane with three people aboard lands safely without landing gear at Newcastle Airport, Australia, Monday, May 13, 2024, after circling the airport for almost three hours to burn off fuel.
media:content.media:description: A light plane with three people aboard lands safely without landing gear at Newcastle Airport, Australia, Monday, May 13, 2024, after circling the airport for almost three hours to burn off fuel.
